tit.e: Higisho (the taking of a religious oath with red-hot iron)
Higisho (the taking of a religious oath with red-hot iron)
Higisho (the taking of a religious oath with red-hot iron)

sen.j: 火起請（ひぎしょう）とは、中世・近世の日本で行われた神判の一種で、鉄火（てっか）・火誓（かせい）とも称する。
sen.e: Higisho is a kind of God's judgment conducted in Japan during the medieval period and modern times, also being referred to as Tekka (red-hot iron) or Kasei (oath of fire).
Higisho is a kind of ordeal believed as God's judgment conducted in Japan during the medieval period and modern times, also being referred to as Tekka (red-hot iron) or Kasei (oath of fire).
sen.cmt: ・追加a kind of God's judgment→a kind of ordeal believed as God's judgment
sen.e: Higisho is a kind of ordeal believed as God's judgment conducted in Japan during the medieval period and modern times, also being referred to as Tekka (red-hot iron) or Kasei (oath of fire).

sen.j: 赤く焼けた鉄（鉄片・鉄棒）を手に受けさせ、歩いて神棚の上まで持ち運ぶなどの行為の成否をもって主張の当否を判断した。
sen.e: People were forced to catch red-hot iron (an iron piece or bar) with their hands and to walk to kamidana (a household Shinto altar) carrying it, and if they succeeded, their claim was judged to be right.

People catched red-hot iron (an iron piece or bar) with their hands and walked to kamidana (a household Shinto altar) carrying it, and if they succeeded in the trial, their claim was judged to be right.

sen.e: People catched red-hot iron (an iron piece or bar) with their hands and walked to kamidana (a household Shinto altar) carrying it, and if they succeeded in the trial, their claim was judged to be right.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代初期にかけての境相論の際に行われることが殆どであり、相論の是非が定まらなかった場合に、神の判断を仰ぐ意図の元に行われた。
sen.e: Higisho was mostly conducted during disputes over the boundaries of territories from the Sengoku period to the early Edo period, for the purpose of seeking God's judgment when such disputes cannot be settled.

Higisho was mostly conducted during disputes over the boundaries of territories from the Sengoku (civil war) period to the early Edo period, for the purpose of seeking God's judgment when such disputes cannot be settled.
sen.cmt: ・戦国時代を説明する表現を追加the Sengoku period→the Sengoku (civil war) period
sen.e: Higisho was mostly conducted during disputes over the boundaries of territories from the Sengoku (civil war) period to the early Edo period, for the purpose of seeking God's judgment when such disputes cannot be settled.

sen.j: 相論の対象となる集団からそれぞれ代表者を指名し、代表者は精進潔斎の上に立会いの役人らの前で掌に牛王宝印を広げ、その上に灼熱した鉄を乗せて、それを素手で持ち運びその完遂の度合いによって所属集団の主張の当否が判断された。
sen.e: Representatives who were selected from each of the disputing groups, after purifying themselves by abstaining from eating meat, spread Gohoin on their palm, held red-hot iron onto it and carried the iron with their bare hands in front of accompanying government officials, and appropriateness of the group they belonged to was determined according to the degree they succeeded in carrying the iron.

Representatives who were selected from each of the disputing groups, after purifying themselves by abstaining from eating meat, spread Gohoins (talisman) on their palms, held red-hot iron onto them and carried the iron with their bare hands in front of presenting government officials, then validity of the claims from their belonging groups was determined according to the degree of their accomplishment.

sen.e: Representatives who were selected from each of the disputing groups, after purifying themselves by abstaining from eating meat, spread Gohoins (talisman) on their palms, held red-hot iron onto them and carried the iron with their bare hands in front of presenting government officials, then validity of the claims from their belonging groups was determined according to the degree of their accomplishment.

sen.j: もし、成功しなかった場合はその集団の敗北とされ、代表者は神を欺いた罰として引廻・斬首などになり、極端な場合には五体引き裂かれた上に引き裂かれたままの遺骸を埋めた塚を複数個設置してその線上を境界線とした例もあった。
sen.e: If a representative failed, his group was deemed to lose the dispute and he was dragged around the city or decapitated as punishment for trying to deceive God, or in extreme cases, he was torn apart into five pieces (hands, legs and head) and several mounds under which the torn pieces of mortal remains were buried were established in a line and used as boundaries.

If a representative failed, his group was deemed to lose the dispute and he was dragged around the city or decapitated as punishment for trying to deceive God, or in extreme cases, he was torn apart into five pieces (hands, legs and head) and several mounds under which the torn pieces of mortal remains were buried were built in a line and defined as boundaries.

sen.j: また、勝った代表者も火傷などによって不具になる場合も珍しくなかった。
sen.e: Even if a representative won, he got maimed due to burn injuries in many cases.

sen.j: このため、勝っても負けても火起請を行った代表者あるいはその家族はその集団が責任をもって面倒を見るべきものとされた。
sen.e: That is why it was believed that a group should be responsible for taking care of its representative who had joined higisho and his family, whether he won or not.
Therefore, it was commonly considered that a group should be responsible for taking care of its representative who had undergone higisho and his family, whether he won or not.

sen.j: 火起請の記録は会津地方や近江国など各地に見られ、また火起請の結果築かれたと伝えられる「鉄火塚」と呼ばれる塚が残っている地域も存在する。
sen.e: Cases of higisho were recorded all over Japan, including the Aizu Region and the Omi Province, and mounds called "tekka zuka" (a grave for red-hot iron), which are said to have been built as a result of higisho, remain in some areas.
